abstracts.cdata!:
This Project Completion note has been
            issued instead of an Implementation Completion Report, in
            accordance with Paragraph 4 of OP 13.55, that deals with
            Implementation Completion Reporting, since the Project falls
            in one of the exceptional cases provided therein, as the
            Project was terminated before significant implementation
            could be initiated. The overall purpose of the project was
            to improve transport conditions along a strategic highway
            corrisor linking Bogota with Medelllin and the ports on the
            north coast, through an effective and sustainable
            private-public partnership. The early termination of the
            concession has made impossible the attainment of the Project
            objectives in the manner and timeframe envisaged at
            appraisal. It also left the construction works along Link 3
            incomplete. Although earthworks were done on some
            unconnected sections along the alignment, construction of
            tunnels and main viaducts--the bulk and more complex part of
            the investment--never began.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Toll Road Concession Project aims to
            improve transport conditions along a strategic road corridor
            linking Bogota with Medellin and the ports on the north
            coast through an effective and sustainable private-public
            partnership. There are 3 components. The first comprises the
            project works to be undertaken during the construction phase
            of the concession. They entail re-building, operating, and
            maintaining existing roads; constructing a new highway; and
            establishing and managing a natural reserve of sub-Andean
            forest to offset the project's environmental impact.
            Road improvements include an asphalt concrete overlay and
            improvements to sections in critical condition due to
            recurring landslides and drainage deficiencies; tunnels,
            bridges, and viaducts; and repaving works needed to maintain
            the level of service along the road network assigned to the
            concessionaire and to build the infrastructure needed to
            collect tolls and operate the natural reserve along the Rio
            Negro. The second component comprises 1) all the studies and
            services needed to develop and manage the project, finalize
            the engineering designs, and assure quality control of
            construction and operation activities during the
            pre-construction and construction phases; and 2) external
            supervision services to be hired to oversee the execution of
            the concession contract. The third component comprises
            project expenditures related to construction that are needed
            to mobilize private financing.

repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - Puerto Salgar Road Project -
            environmental impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment of
            the Tobiagrande-Puerto Salgar Road Project, which completes
            the road project begun in 1953 as the Bogota-Medellin
            highway. The main negative, geophysical impacts are the
            generation of geomorphic-dynamic processes resulting from
            the formation of slopes and the instability arising in
            streams. Negative impacts include loss of vegetal cover
            resulting from leveling and grading activities, wildlife
            migration due to loss of natural habitat, noise caused by
            machinery and blasting work, and deterioration in water
            quality caused by materials falling into the beds of rivers
            and streams, which can in extreme cases result in water
            courses overflowing and causing avalanches. Contractors will
            deposit waste material generated from stripping,
            exploration, and general land preparation activities so as
            to avoid obstructing natural or artificial water courses;
            the vegetal layer removed from land will be used as planting
            to protect slopes. Waste disposal areas will be restored by
            replanting slopes with material stripped from their original
            areas. To prevent periodic rises in water level caused by
            the river overflowing its banks, a channel will be built. A
            forestry reserve will be established to preserve natural
            vegetation and offset erosion, maintain a wildlife refuge
            and protect water sources. Water and air quality analyses
            will be carried out. Displaced families will be resettled,
            demolished schools rebuilt elsewhere, and cattle crossings reconstructed.

docna.cdata!:
Colombia - Puerto Salgar Road Project -
            environmental impact assessment

display_title.display_title:
Colombia - Proyecto de la
            Carretera Puerto Salgar: Evaluación del impacto ambiental
            (Vol. 4)

authors.authr:
Enrique Davila Lozano-E.D.L. LTDA.,
            Consultant Engineers
